fields.name: Install a low-flow sink aerator
fields.content: If every household in the United States installed low-flow faucet accessories, we could save about $600 million in annual energy costs from heating water.

fields.name: Use your ceiling fan in the winter
fields.content: Your fan can be a windfall for energy savings all year long.
fields.teaser: Use your ceiling fan in the winter

fields.name: Use motion sensors and/or timers for "always-on" lights
fields.content: Leaving a light on can be convenient, but you end up wasting hours of electricity when you only need a few minutes. Motion sensors and timers provide easy fixes.
fields.teaser: Use motion sensors and/or timers for "always-on" lights

fields.name: Keep your fireplace damper closed
fields.content: Your fireplace is supposed to keep you warm, but leaky fireplaces often make your house colder by drawing warm air up the flue.

fields.name: Install a low-flow shower head
fields.content: According to the EPA, the average household would save 300 kilowatt hours of electricity annually by installing low-flow shower heads. That's enough electricity to power your household's television for about a year.

fields.name: Replace one light bulb with a CFL
fields.content: Incandescent bulbs are outdated and cost you way too much. Virtually every light in your home could be using 75% less energy, and responsible for 75% fewer carbon emissions, if you switch you CFLs.
fields.teaser: Replace one light bulb with a CFL

fields.name: Seal off vents in unoccupied rooms
fields.content: If you have central air, closing vents or installing magnetic vent covers allows you to control the air flow in unoccupied rooms.
fields.teaser: Seal off vents in unoccupied rooms

fields.name: Replace half of your home's light bulbs with CFLs
fields.content: Incandescent bulbs are outdated and cost you way too much. Virtually every light in your home could be using 75% less energy, and responsible for 75% fewer carbon emissions, if you switch you CFLs.
fields.teaser: Replace half of your home's light bulbs with CFLs

fields.name: Replace all of your home's light bulbs with CFLs
fields.content: Incandescent bulbs are outdated and cost you way too much. Virtually every light in your home could be using 75% less energy, and responsible for 75% fewer carbon emissions, if you switch you CFLs.
fields.teaser: Replace all of your home's light bulbs with CFLs

fields.name: Dial down your thermostat when you're at home
fields.content: Programmable thermostats help lower your heating and cooling costs when you're away from the home, but you can achieve additional savings by turning back the temperature when you're at home, too.

fields.name: Wash your clothes in cold water
fields.content: Only 10% of the energy used by your washing machine goes to turning the clothes; the other 90% is used up heating your hot water.
fields.teaser: Wash your clothes in cold water

fields.name: Cut standby power
fields.content: Many of your electronic devices are using more than 75% more energy than they need.

fields.name: Use a programmable thermostat
fields.content: Stop wasting money on heating and cooling an empty house. Right now, you could easily be saving 7% on heating and cooling if you use a programmable thermostat correctly.

fields.name: Have a home inspection
fields.content: A home inspection will give you the tools to understand and unlock your home's energy saving potential. By becoming better-informed about your home, you can make targeted upgrades that will dramatically improve your home's performance.

fields.name: Adjust the temperature setting on your water heater
fields.content: Many water heaters are set by the manufacturer at 140Â°F. This is hotter than most households need, and a setting that high risks exposing you to scalding hot water. Turning back the temperature on your water heater can save you 10% or more in heating costs.
fields.teaser: Adjust the temperature setting on your water heater

fields.name: Insulate your water heater
fields.content: If the outside of your water heater feels warm, heat is escaping and your system could benefit from additional insulation.

fields.name: Replace your outdated refrigerator
fields.content: An Energy Star-rated refrigerator gives your kitchen a sleek, fresh look while saving a ton of energy. If your refrigerator is more than 8 years old, it likely uses more than twice as much electricity as an udated refrigerator.
